11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-011-9505-z950510.1007/s11243-011-9505-zArticleFour complexes with a bulky carboxylate ligand: syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent propertiesWangJun-Jie1aZhuHui-Min1WangShao-Mei1grid.459341.e0000000417589923School of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringAnyang Normal University455002Anyang, HenanPeople’s Republic of China+86-2900040adamwjj_611@mail.nankai.edu.cn1262011820113655795842352011263201123520111262011© Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 20112011Abstract

Four complexes of 3,3-diphenylpropanoate (L) and 4,4′-bipyridine as auxiliary bridging ligands were synthesized and characterized, namely [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1), [Co(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (2), [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3), and [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4) (4bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine). X-ray single-crystal diffraction analyses show that complexes 1–4 all take one-dimensional (1D) fishbone-like structures incorporating bridging 4bpy ligands. The complexes show different supramolecular frameworks interlinked via intermolecular hydrogen bonds, π···π stacking, and/or C–H···π supramolecular interactions. Complex 3 only has a simple one-dimensional fishbone-like chain, whereas complexes 1 and 2 show two-dimensional supramolecular structures by interchain C–H···O hydrogen bonds. Complex 4 is assembled into two-dimensional layers and then an overall three-dimensional framework by a combination of interchain O–H···O hydrogen bonds and C–H···π supramolecular interactions. The luminescent properties of the ligands and their complexes were investigated.

Graphical Abstract

Our new ZnII, CoII, NiII and CuII complexes have been successfully achieved by using 3,3-diphenylpropanoate ligands, together with 4,4′-bipyridine auxiliary bridging ligands. The structural variations of the four complexes, compared to these of related ligands, can be attributed to the substituents of L. The luminescent properties of the complexes were investigated.

Introduction

Metal complexes have potential applications in molecular adsorption and separation processes, gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, sensor technology, and so on [1–3]. In this field, the choice of suitable organic ligands favoring structure-specific self-assembly is crucial for the construction of coordination structures with relevant properties and functions [4]. In this context, carboxylic acid ligands, especially benzene- and naphthalene-based carboxylic acids such as 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid [5], 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid [6], 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid [6–8], 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid [6, 8, 9], 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid [10], and naphthalene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid [11], have been well used in the preparation of various MII–carboxylate complexes owing to their rich coordination modes. In contrast, the use of monocarboxylic acid ligands with bulky backbones to construct functional MII–carboxylate compounds has been less investigated to date. Ligand substituents, as well as auxiliary ligands, counteranions, the pH of the reaction, temperature, reactants molar ratio, and solvent [12], can not only play an important role in the formation of such complexes but also influence their structures and functions.

In our previous work, four monocarboxylate ligands bearing different substituent groups, namely anthracene-9-carboxylic acid [13–17], phenanthrene-9-carboxylic acid [18], 2-phenylquinoline-4-carboxylic acid [18], and adamantane-1-carboxylic acid [18], were used to construct AgI, CuII, CoII, NiII, MnII, and CdII complexes, which exhibited interesting magnetic and luminescent properties. In this work, we selected a representative ligand with bulky substituents, 3,3-diphenylpropanoic acid (HL) (Chart 1), as a primary ligand, together with 4,4′-bipyridine (4bpy) as a bridging auxiliary ligand, to construct a series of transition metal coordination polymers, namely [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1), [Co(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (2), [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3), and [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4). The ligand L bearing a large conjugated π-system and steric hindrance may play an important role in the formation of supramolecular frameworks. The luminescence properties of the corresponding complexes and ligands have been investigated.

Experimental

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received, or purified by standard methods. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4,000–400 cm−1 on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer.

Preparation of [Zn(<bold>L</bold>)<sub>2</sub>(4bpy)(EtOH)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of HL (0.05 mmol) and 4bpy (0.05 mmol) in EtOH (10 mL) in the presence of excess 2,6-dimethylpyridine (ca. 0.05 mL for adjusting the pH to basic condition) was carefully layered on the top of an H2O solution (15 mL) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 mmol) in a test tube. Colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature. Yield: ca. 30% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H46N2O6Zn: C, 69.3; H, 6.1; N, 3.7; found (%): C, 68.9; H, 6.4; N, 3.4. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,642s(br), 3,025m, 1,957w, 1,599s, 1,568s, 1,494m, 1,449m, 1,409s, 1,310m, 1,220m, 1,086w, 1,063m, 1,002w, 967w, 902w, 853w, 806s, 749m, 703s, 625m, 611m, 587w, 543w, 473w.

Preparation of [Co(<bold>L</bold>)<sub>2</sub>(4bpy) EtOH)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

The same procedure as that for 1 was used for this complex except that Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was replaced by Co(NO3)2·6H2O. Light red single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature. Yield: ca. 30% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H46N2O6Co: C, 69.7; H, 6.1; N, 3.7; found (%): C, 70.0; H, 6.5; N, 3.5. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,418s(br), 3,237w, 2,971w, 2,038w, 1,640s, 1,617s, 1,561w, 1,453s, 1,217m, 1,140m, 1,060m, 1031m, 879w, 849m, 822w, 811w, 749w, 612s, 494w.

Preparation of [Ni(<bold>L</bold>)<sub>2</sub>(4bpy)(EtOH)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

The same procedure as that for 1 was used for this complex except that Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was replaced by Ni(Ac)2·4H2O. Green single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature Yield: ca. 40% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H46N2O6Ni: C, 69.8; H, 6.1; N, 3.7; found (%): C, 70.0; H, 6.4; N, 3.4. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,472s(br), 3,237w, 2,511w, 2,038w, 1,688w, 1,640s, 1,618s, 1,564w, 1,456s, 1,132m, 1,029w, 879w, 848m, 816w, 617s.

Preparation of [Cu(<bold>L</bold>)<sub>2</sub>(4bpy)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

The same procedure as that for 1 was used for this complex except that Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was replaced by CuSO4·5H2O. Light blue single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature. Yield: ca. 30% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C40H36N2O5Cu: C, 69.9; H, 5.3; N, 4.1; found (%): C, 69.7; H, 5.5; N, 4.4. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,464s(br), 1,604s, 1,450s, 1,402s, 1,303w, 1,221m, 1,151m, 1,066m, 1,032m, 971w, 900w, 879w, 849m, 810m, 756w, 734w, 705w, 691m, 609m, 483w.

X-ray powder diffraction studies of <bold>1–4</bold>

The X-ray powder diffraction patterns (XRPD) of complexes 1–4 were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer, operated at 40 kV and 100 mA, using a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. The intensity data were recorded by continuous scan in a 2θ/θ mode from 3° to 80° with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 8° min−1.

X-ray crystallographic studies of <bold>1–4</bold>

X-ray single-crystal diffraction for complexes 1–4 was measured on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection at 293(2) K. The determinations of unit cell parameters and data collections were made with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), and unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-square refinements. The program SAINT [19] was used for the integration of the diffraction profiles. Semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program [20]. All structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL [21]. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F2. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water were added theoretically, riding on the concerned atoms and refined with fixed thermal factors. The hydrogen atoms of water have been found in Fourier map and refined freely. Crystallographic data and experimental details for the structures are shown in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table 2. CCDC nos.790394–790397 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for complexes 1–4. This material can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

Results and discussionSynthesis and general characterization

The synthesis and isolation of complexes 1–4 were carried out by the reaction of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Ni(Ac)2·4H2O, or CuSO4·5H2O with HL, together with 4,4′-bipyridine as a bridging co-ligand, using the slow diffusion method under ambient temperature and pressure. The use of excess 2,6-dimethylpyridine to adjust the pH of reaction to alkaline is an important factor in the formation of these complexes. Indeed, we have not obtained any complexes suitable for X-ray analysis while using other organic bases, such as Et3N and pyridine. Complexes 1–4 are all air stable. All general characterizations were carried out with crystal samples. As such, the elemental analyses of 1–4 are also consistent with the results of their structural analysis.

Descriptions of the crystal structures

Complexes 1–3 are isostructural except for the different metal centers, ZnII for 1, CoII for 2, and NiII for 3. Here, we describe 1–3 in detail (Fig. 1a and Table 2 for 1, Fig. 1b and Table 2 for 2, and Fig. 1c and Table 2 for 3). X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that each asymmetric unit of 1–3 contains half a MII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and one ethanol ligand. In other words, each MII center is coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, two N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and two O atoms from two EtOH ligands to complete a distorted octahedral coordination environment [M–O = 2.047(2)~2.1436(14) and M–N = 2.122(3)~2.1669(17) Å]. The 4bpy acts as a typical bridging ligand to form a 1D chain structure. All M–N and M–O bond distances as well as the bond angles around each MII center are in the expected ranges [12, 22]. It is worth noting that the dihedral angle between the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy plays an important role in the formation of these supramolecular frameworks. For 1, the 1D chains are assembled to form a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)···O(1B) separation is 3.308(3) Å and C(17)–H(17)···O(1B) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = −x+1, −y, −z+1] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S1). While for 2, the 1D chains are arranged into another 2D sheet by intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)···O(2A) separation is 3.330(4) Å and C(17)–H(17)···O(2A) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = x−1, y, z] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S2). However, there are no such weak interactions in complex 3.

Although complex 4 also has a linear structure, it contains H2O ligands rather than EtOH (Fig. 1d). The asymmetric subunit in 4 is composed of half a CuII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and half an H2O ligand. As shown in Fig. 1a, each CuII is five-coordinated by carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and a single aqua ligand to complete a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment [Cu–O = 1.937(3) and 2.176(7); Cu–N = 2.077(4) Å] [25–27]. Cu(1) is connected to two adjacent CuII centers through the 4bpy bridges to result in a 1D chain.

These 1D chains are assembled to form a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds [the O(1W)···O(1B) separation is 2.693(4) Å and O(1W)–H(1W)···O(1B) angle is 170.14(6)°, symmetry code A = x, y−1, z] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S3a). Meanwhile, in another crystallographic direction, the 1D chains are arranged into another supramolecular 2D sheet by intermolecular C−H···π supramolecular interaction by the edge-to-face orientation between the L and 4bpy rings [d = 3.753(2) Å; A = 150° in the C−H···π patterns] [13, 28, 29] (ESI-Fig. S3b). Finally, the 2D sheets are further linked into a 3D supramolecular network from the different crystallographic directions.

As typical aromatic carboxylate ligands, benzene-based carboxylic acids have been widely used to construct metal–organic coordination architectures [13–17]. The previously reported complexes [Zn3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(paH)(H2O)2.5, [Co3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(4-bpy)(H2O)3.5, and [Co(4bpy)(pa)2(H2O)2](paH)2 (paH = phenylacetic acid) [30], were constructed from paH and 4bpy (Chart 1), showing a 2D 44 framework, a 2D 44 framework, and a 1D chain, respectively. The four new complexes reported in this paper all show similar 1D fishbone-like chain structures. Although HL and paH are similar ligands (see Chart 1), their coordination chemistry is obviously different, presumably as a result of the different substituents. Thus, HL is more sterically hindered than paH, and hence, its complexes show simpler structures. In the supramolecular frameworks, the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy lie at different dihedral angles in complexes 1–4; there is not an obvious rule.

Spectroscopic studies

In general, the IR spectra of these complexes show features attributable to each component [31]. A broad band centered at ca. 3,642–3418 cm−1 is assigned to the O–H stretching of water or EtOH [12, 13, 15, 22]. The characteristic bands of carboxylate groups appeared in the usual regions at 1,640–1,568 cm−1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,456–1,402 cm−1 for the symmetric stretching vibrations [12, 13, 15, 22]. The Δν values [Δν = νas(COO−)−νs(COO−)] are 190 and 159 cm−1 for 1, 187 and 164 cm−1 for 2, 184 and 162 cm−1 for 3,202 and 154 cm−1 for 4, respectively, in good agreement with their s crystal structures [12, 13, 15, 22].

The solid-state luminescences of complexes 1–4 were investigated at room temperature (Fig. 2 and ESI-Figs. S4 and S5). We observed one emission peak at 338 nm for 1 (λex  = 303 nm), one emission peak at 382 nm for 2 (λex  =  279 nm), two emission peaks at 431 and 520 nm for 3 (λex = 380 nm), and two emission peaks at 431 and 520 nm for 4 (λex = 380 nm). Comparing with the emission peak of the free ligand HL at λmax = 383 nm upon excitation at λ = 279 nm, the emission peak of 2 can be tentatively assigned to intraligand charge transfer (LLCT) π*-π transitions, similar to the reported results on coordination polymers [11, 22]. For 1, a blueshift of 45 nm was observed compared with the emission of the free ligand. The emission of complex 1 might be assigned to a combination of CT and intraligand emission states, as reported for other complexes [11]. Complexes 3 and 4 show an obvious redshift relative to the free ligand, which may originate from the emission of 4bpy ligand [11, 22, 32].

XRPD results

To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials used in the luminescence experiments on complexes 1–4, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments have been carried out. The experimental and computer-simulated XRPD patterns of the complexes are shown in ESI-Fig. S6. Although the experimental patterns have a few unindexed diffraction lines and some are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated from the single-crystal modes, it still can be considered that the bulk-synthesized materials and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous.

Conclusion

In conclusion, we successfully obtained ZnII, CoII, NiII, and CuII complexes with 3,3-diphenylpropanoate ligands, together with 4,4′-bipyridine as auxiliary bridging ligands. The structural variations in the four complexes, compared with those of related ligands, can be attributed to the substituents of L. The intra- and/or intermolecular hydrogen bonds and C−H···π supramolecular interactions also play an important role in governing the formation of the crystal frameworks of 1–4. Complexes 1–4 emit strong fluorescence at room temperature, which may make them excellent candidates for purple or greenish purple fluorescent materials.

In this context, carboxylic acid ligands, especially benzene- and naphthalene-based carboxylic acids such as 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid [5], 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid [6], 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid [6-8], 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid [6, 8, 9], 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid [10], and naphthalene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid [11], have been well used in the preparation of various MII-carboxylate complexes owing to their rich coordination modes. In contrast, the use of monocarboxylic acid ligands with bulky backbones to construct functional MII-carboxylate compounds has been less investigated to date. Ligand substituents, as well as auxiliary ligands, counteranions, the pH of the reaction, temperature, reactants molar ratio, and solvent [12], can not only play an important role in the formation of such complexes but also influence their structures and functions.In our previous work, four monocarboxylate ligands bearing different substituent groups, namely anthracene-9-carboxylic acid [13-17], phenanthrene-9-carboxylic acid [18], 2-phenylquinoline-4-carboxylic acid [18], and adamantane-1-carboxylic acid [18], were used to construct AgI, CuII, CoII, NiII, MnII, and CdII complexes, which exhibited interesting magnetic and luminescent properties. In this work, we selected a representative ligand with bulky substituents, 3,3-diphenylpropanoic acid (HL) (Chart 1), as a primary ligand, together with 4,4'-bipyridine (4bpy) as a bridging auxiliary ligand, to construct a series of transition metal coordination polymers, namely [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1), [Co(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (2), [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3), and [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4). The ligand L bearing a large conjugated π-system and steric hindrance may play an important role in the formation of supramolecular frameworks. The luminescence properties of the corresponding complexes and ligands have been investigated.ExperimentalAll reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received, or purified by standard methods. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4,000-400 cm-1 on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer.Preparation of [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1)A solution of HL (0.05 mmol) and 4bpy (0.05 mmol) in EtOH (10 mL) in the presence of excess 2,6-dimethylpyridine (ca. 0.05 mL for adjusting the pH to basic condition) was carefully layered on the top of an H2O solution (15 mL) of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.05 mmol) in a test tube. Colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature. Yield: ca. 30% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H46N2O6Zn: C, 69.3; H, 6.1; N, 3.7; found (%): C, 68.9; H, 6.4; N, 3.4. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3,642s(br), 3,025m, 1,957w, 1,599s, 1,568s, 1,494m, 1,449m, 1,409s, 1,310m, 1,220m, 1,086w, 1,063m, 1,002w, 967w, 902w, 853w, 806s, 749m, 703s, 625m, 611m, 587w, 543w, 473w.Preparation of [Co(L)2(4bpy) EtOH)2]∞ (2)The same procedure as that for 1 was used for this complex except that Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was replaced by Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O. Light red single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature. Yield: ca. 30% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H46N2O6Co: C, 69.7; H, 6.1; N, 3.7; found (%): C, 70.0; H, 6.5; N, 3.5. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3,418s(br), 3,237w, 2,971w, 2,038w, 1,640s, 1,617s, 1,561w, 1,453s, 1,217m, 1,140m, 1,060m, 1031m, 879w, 849m, 822w, 811w, 749w, 612s, 494w.Preparation of [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3)The same procedure as that for 1 was used for this complex except that Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was replaced by Ni(Ac)2⋅4H2O. Green single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature Yield: ca. 40% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H46N2O6Ni: C, 69.8; H, 6.1; N, 3.7; found (%): C, 70.0; H, 6.4; N, 3.4. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3,472s(br), 3,237w, 2,511w, 2,038w, 1,688w, 1,640s, 1,618s, 1,564w, 1,456s, 1,132m, 1,029w, 879w, 848m, 816w, 617s.Preparation of [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4)The same procedure as that for 1 was used for this complex except that Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was replaced by CuSO4⋅5H2O. Light blue single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis appeared at the tube wall after ca. 1 month at room temperature. Yield: ca. 30% based on HL. Anal. Calcd (%) for C40H36N2O5Cu: C, 69.9; H, 5.3; N, 4.1; found (%): C, 69.7; H, 5.5; N, 4.4. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3,464s(br), 1,604s, 1,450s, 1,402s, 1,303w, 1,221m, 1,151m, 1,066m, 1,032m, 971w, 900w, 879w, 849m, 810m, 756w, 734w, 705w, 691m, 609m, 483w.X-ray powder diffraction studies of 1-4The X-ray powder diffraction patterns (XRPD) of complexes 1-4 were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer, operated at 40 kV and 100 mA, using a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. The intensity data were recorded by continuous scan in a 2θ/θ mode from 3° to 80° with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 8° min-1.X-ray crystallographic studies of 1-4X-ray single-crystal diffraction for complexes 1-4 was measured on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection at 293(2) K. The determinations of unit cell parameters and data collections were made with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), and unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-square refinements. The program SAINT [19] was used for the integration of the diffraction profiles. Semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program [20]. All structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL [21]. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F2. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water were added theoretically, riding on the concerned atoms and refined with fixed thermal factors. The hydrogen atoms of water have been found in Fourier map and refined freely. Crystallographic data and experimental details for the structures are shown in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table 2. CCDC nos.790394-790397 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for complexes 1-4. This material can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.Results and discussionSynthesis and general characterizationThe synthesis and isolation of complexes 1-4 were carried out by the reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Ni(Ac)2⋅4H2O, or CuSO4⋅5H2O with HL, together with 4,4'-bipyridine as a bridging co-ligand, using the slow diffusion method under ambient temperature and pressure. The use of excess 2,6-dimethylpyridine to adjust the pH of reaction to alkaline is an important factor in the formation of these complexes. Indeed, we have not obtained any complexes suitable for X-ray analysis while using other organic bases, such as Et3N and pyridine. Complexes 1-4 are all air stable. All general characterizations were carried out with crystal samples. As such, the elemental analyses of 1-4 are also consistent with the results of their structural analysis.Descriptions of the crystal structuresComplexes 1-3 are isostructural except for the different metal centers, ZnII for 1, CoII for 2, and NiII for 3. Here, we describe 1-3 in detail (Fig. 1a and Table 2 for 1, Fig. 1b and Table 2 for 2, and Fig. 1c and Table 2 for 3). X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that each asymmetric unit of 1-3 contains half a MII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and one ethanol ligand. In other words, each MII center is coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, two N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and two O atoms from two EtOH ligands to complete a distorted octahedral coordination environment [M-O = 2.047(2)~2.1436(14) and M-N = 2.122(3)~2.1669(17) Å]. The 4bpy acts as a typical bridging ligand to form a 1D chain structure. All M-N and M-O bond distances as well as the bond angles around each MII center are in the expected ranges [12, 22]. It is worth noting that the dihedral angle between the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy plays an important role in the formation of these supramolecular frameworks. For 1, the 1D chains are assembled to form a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)⋅⋅⋅O(1B) separation is 3.308(3) Å and C(17)-H(17)⋅⋅⋅O(1B) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = -x+1, -y, -z+1] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S1). While for 2, the 1D chains are arranged into another 2D sheet by intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)⋅⋅⋅O(2A) separation is 3.330(4) Å and C(17)-H(17)⋅⋅⋅O(2A) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = x-1, y, z] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S2). However, there are no such weak interactions in complex 3.Although complex 4 also has a linear structure, it contains H2O ligands rather than EtOH (Fig. 1d). The asymmetric subunit in 4 is composed of half a CuII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and half an H2O ligand. As shown in Fig. 1a, each CuII is five-coordinated by carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and a single aqua ligand to complete a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment [Cu-O = 1.937(3) and 2.176(7); Cu-N = 2.077(4) Å] [25-27]. Cu(1) is connected to two adjacent CuII centers through the 4bpy bridges to result in a 1D chain.These 1D chains are assembled to form a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds [the O(1W)⋅⋅⋅O(1B) separation is 2.693(4) Å and O(1W)-H(1W)⋅⋅⋅O(1B) angle is 170.14(6)°, symmetry code A = x, y-1, z] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S3a). Meanwhile, in another crystallographic direction, the 1D chains are arranged into another supramolecular 2D sheet by intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interaction by the edge-to-face orientation between the L and 4bpy rings [d = 3.753(2) Å; A = 150° in the C-H⋅⋅⋅π patterns] [13, 28, 29] (ESI-Fig. S3b). Finally, the 2D sheets are further linked into a 3D supramolecular network from the different crystallographic directions.As typical aromatic carboxylate ligands, benzene-based carboxylic acids have been widely used to construct metal-organic coordination architectures [13-17]. The previously reported complexes [Zn3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(paH)(H2O)2.5, [Co3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(4-bpy)(H2O)3.5, and [Co(4bpy)(pa)2(H2O)2](paH)2 (paH = phenylacetic acid) [30], were constructed from paH and 4bpy (Chart 1), showing a 2D 44 framework, a 2D 44 framework, and a 1D chain, respectively. The four new complexes reported in this paper all show similar 1D fishbone-like chain structures. Although HL and paH are similar ligands (see Chart 1), their coordination chemistry is obviously different, presumably as a result of the different substituents. Thus, HL is more sterically hindered than paH, and hence, its complexes show simpler structures. In the supramolecular frameworks, the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy lie at different dihedral angles in complexes 1-4; there is not an obvious rule.Spectroscopic studiesIn general, the IR spectra of these complexes show features attributable to each component [31]. A broad band centered at ca. 3,642-3418 cm-1 is assigned to the O-H stretching of water or EtOH [12, 13, 15, 22]. The characteristic bands of carboxylate groups appeared in the usual regions at 1,640-1,568 cm-1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,456-1,402 cm-1 for the symmetric stretching vibrations [12, 13, 15, 22]. The Δν values [Δν = νas(COO-)-νs(COO-)] are 190 and 159 cm-1 for 1, 187 and 164 cm-1 for 2, 184 and 162 cm-1 for 3,202 and 154 cm-1 for 4, respectively, in good agreement with their s crystal structures [12, 13, 15, 22].The solid-state luminescences of complexes 1-4 were investigated at room temperature (Fig. 2 and ESI-Figs. S4 and S5). We observed one emission peak at 338 nm for 1 (λex  = 303 nm), one emission peak at 382 nm for 2 (λex  =  279 nm), two emission peaks at 431 and 520 nm for 3 (λex = 380 nm), and two emission peaks at 431 and 520 nm for 4 (λex = 380 nm). Comparing with the emission peak of the free ligand HL at λmax = 383 nm upon excitation at λ = 279 nm, the emission peak of 2 can be tentatively assigned to intraligand charge transfer (LLCT) π*-π transitions, similar to the reported results on coordination polymers [11, 22]. For 1, a blueshift of 45 nm was observed compared with the emission of the free ligand. The emission of complex 1 might be assigned to a combination of CT and intraligand emission states, as reported for other complexes [11]. Complexes 3 and 4 show an obvious redshift relative to the free ligand, which may originate from the emission of 4bpy ligand [11, 22, 32].XRPD resultsTo confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials used in the luminescence experiments on complexes 1-4, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments have been carried out. The experimental and computer-simulated XRPD patterns of the complexes are shown in ESI-Fig. S6. Although the experimental patterns have a few unindexed diffraction lines and some are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated from the single-crystal modes, it still can be considered that the bulk-synthesized materials and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous.ConclusionIn conclusion, we successfully obtained ZnII, CoII, NiII, and CuII complexes with 3,3-diphenylpropanoate ligands, together with 4,4'-bipyridine as auxiliary bridging ligands. The structural variations in the four complexes, compared with those of related ligands, can be attributed to the substituents of L. The intra- and/or intermolecular hydrogen bonds and C-H⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interactions also play an important role in governing the formation of the crystal frameworks of 1-4. Complexes 1-4 emit strong fluorescence at room temperature, which may make them excellent candidates for purple or greenish purple fluorescent materials.AcknowledgmentsThis work was financially elements.content: Four complexes of 3,3-diphenylpropanoate (L) and 4,4′-bipyridine as auxiliary bridging ligands were synthesized and characterized, namely [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1), [Co(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (2), [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3), and [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4) (4bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine). X-ray single-crystal diffraction analyses show that complexes 1–4 all take one-dimensional (1D) fishbone-like structures incorporating bridging 4bpy ligands. The complexes show different supramolecular frameworks interlinked via intermolecular hydrogen bonds, π···π stacking, and/or C–H···π supramolecular interactions. Complex 3 only has a simple one-dimensional fishbone-like chain, whereas complexes 1 and 2 show two-dimensional supramolecular structures by interchain C–H···O hydrogen bonds. Complex 4 is assembled into two-dimensional layers and then an overall three-dimensional framework by a combination of interchain O–H···O hydrogen bonds and C–H···π supramolecular interactions. The luminescent properties of the ligands and their complexes were investigated.

Abstract

Four complexes of 3,3-diphenylpropanoate (L) and 4,4'-bipyridine as auxiliary bridging ligands were synthesized and characterized, namely [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1), [Co(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (2), [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3), and [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4) (4bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine). X-ray single-crystal diffraction analyses show that complexes 1-4 all take one-dimensional (1D) fishbone-like structures incorporating bridging 4bpy ligands. The complexes show different supramolecular frameworks interlinked via intermolecular hydrogen bonds, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking, and/or C-H⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interactions. Complex 3 only has a simple one-dimensional fishbone-like chain, whereas complexes 1 and 2 show two-dimensional supramolecular structures by interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. Complex 4 is assembled into two-dimensional layers and then an overall three-dimensional framework by a combination of interchain O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds and C-H⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interactions. The luminescent properties of the ligands and their complexes were investigated.

Graphical Abstract

Our new ZnII, CoII, NiII and CuII complexes have been successfully achieved by using 3,3-diphenylpropanoate ligands, together with 4,4'-bipyridine auxiliary bridging ligands. The structural variations of the four complexes, compared to these of related ligands, can be attributed to the substituents of L. The luminescent properties of the complexes were investigated.

Introduction

Metal complexes have potential applications in molecular adsorption and separation processes, gas storage, ion exchange, catalysis, sensor technology, and so on [1-3]. In this field, the choice of suitable organic ligands favoring structure-specific self-assembly is crucial for the construction of coordination structures with relevant properties and functions [4]. In this context, carboxylic acid ligands, especially benzene- and naphthalene-based carboxylic acids such as 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid [5], 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid [6], 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid [6-8], 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid [6, 8, 9], 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid [10], and naphthalene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid [11], have been well used in the preparation of various MII-carboxylate complexes owing to their rich coordination modes. In contrast, the use of monocarboxylic acid ligands with bulky backbones to construct functional MII-carboxylate compounds has been less investigated to date. Ligand substituents, as well as auxiliary ligands, counteranions, the pH of the reaction, temperature, reactants molar ratio, and solvent [12], can not only play an important role in the formation of such complexes but also influence their structures and functions.

elements.content: In our previous work, four monocarboxylate ligands bearing different substituent groups, namely anthracene-9-carboxylic acid [13–17], phenanthrene-9-carboxylic acid [18], 2-phenylquinoline-4-carboxylic acid [18], and adamantane-1-carboxylic acid [18], were used to construct AgI, CuII, CoII, NiII, MnII, and CdII complexes, which exhibited interesting magnetic and luminescent properties. In this work, we selected a representative ligand with bulky substituents, 3,3-diphenylpropanoic acid (HL) (Chart 1), as a primary ligand, together with 4,4′-bipyridine (4bpy) as a bridging auxiliary ligand, to construct a series of transition metal coordination polymers, namely [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1), [Co(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (2), [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3), and [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4). The ligand L bearing a large conjugated π-system and steric hindrance may play an important role in the formation of supramolecular frameworks. The luminescence properties of the corresponding complexes and ligands have been investigated.
elements.clean_text: In our previous work, four monocarboxylate ligands bearing different substituent groups, namely anthracene-9-carboxylic acid [13-17], phenanthrene-9-carboxylic acid [18], 2-phenylquinoline-4-carboxylic acid [18], and adamantane-1-carboxylic acid [18], were used to construct AgI, CuII, CoII, NiII, MnII, and CdII complexes, which exhibited interesting magnetic and luminescent properties. In this work, we selected a representative ligand with bulky substituents, 3,3-diphenylpropanoic acid (HL) (Chart 1), as a primary ligand, together with 4,4'-bipyridine (4bpy) as a bridging auxiliary ligand, to construct a series of transition metal coordination polymers, namely [Zn(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (1), [Co(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (2), [Ni(L)2(4bpy)(EtOH)2]∞ (3), and [Cu(L)2(4bpy)(H2O)]∞ (4). The ligand L bearing a large conjugated π-system and steric hindrance may play an important role in the formation of supramolecular frameworks. The luminescence properties of the corresponding complexes and ligands have been investigated.

X-ray powder diffraction studies of 1-4

The X-ray powder diffraction patterns (XRPD) of complexes 1-4 were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer, operated at 40 kV and 100 mA, using a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. The intensity data were recorded by continuous scan in a 2θ/θ mode from 3° to 80° with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 8° min-1.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction for complexes 1–4 was measured on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection at 293(2) K. The determinations of unit cell parameters and data collections were made with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), and unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-square refinements. The program SAINT [19] was used for the integration of the diffraction profiles. Semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program [20]. All structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL [21]. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F2. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water were added theoretically, riding on the concerned atoms and refined with fixed thermal factors. The hydrogen atoms of water have been found in Fourier map and refined freely. Crystallographic data and experimental details for the structures are shown in Table 1. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table 2. CCDC nos.790394–790397 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for complexes 1–4. This material can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; or E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and general characterization

The synthesis and isolation of complexes 1-4 were carried out by the reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Ni(Ac)2⋅4H2O, or CuSO4⋅5H2O with HL, together with 4,4'-bipyridine as a bridging co-ligand, using the slow diffusion method under ambient temperature and pressure. The use of excess 2,6-dimethylpyridine to adjust the pH of reaction to alkaline is an important factor in the formation of these complexes. Indeed, we have not obtained any complexes suitable for X-ray analysis while using other organic bases, such as Et3N and pyridine. Complexes 1-4 are all air stable. All general characterizations were carried out with crystal samples. As such, the elemental analyses of 1-4 are also consistent with the results of their structural analysis.

elements.content: Complexes 1–3 are isostructural except for the different metal centers, ZnII for 1, CoII for 2, and NiII for 3. Here, we describe 1–3 in detail (Fig. 1a and Table 2 for 1, Fig. 1b and Table 2 for 2, and Fig. 1c and Table 2 for 3). X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that each asymmetric unit of 1–3 contains half a MII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and one ethanol ligand. In other words, each MII center is coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, two N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and two O atoms from two EtOH ligands to complete a distorted octahedral coordination environment [M–O = 2.047(2)~2.1436(14) and M–N = 2.122(3)~2.1669(17) Å]. The 4bpy acts as a typical bridging ligand to form a 1D chain structure. All M–N and M–O bond distances as well as the bond angles around each MII center are in the expected ranges [12, 22]. It is worth noting that the dihedral angle between the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy plays an important role in the formation of these supramolecular frameworks. For 1, the 1D chains are assembled to form a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)···O(1B) separation is 3.308(3) Å and C(17)–H(17)···O(1B) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = −x+1, −y, −z+1] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S1). While for 2, the 1D chains are arranged into another 2D sheet by intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)···O(2A) separation is 3.330(4) Å and C(17)–H(17)···O(2A) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = x−1, y, z] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S2). However, there are no such weak interactions in complex 3.
elements.clean_text:
Descriptions of the crystal structures

Complexes 1-3 are isostructural except for the different metal centers, ZnII for 1, CoII for 2, and NiII for 3. Here, we describe 1-3 in detail (Fig. 1a and Table 2 for 1, Fig. 1b and Table 2 for 2, and Fig. 1c and Table 2 for 3). X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis reveals that each asymmetric unit of 1-3 contains half a MII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and one ethanol ligand. In other words, each MII center is coordinated by two carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, two N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and two O atoms from two EtOH ligands to complete a distorted octahedral coordination environment [M-O = 2.047(2)~2.1436(14) and M-N = 2.122(3)~2.1669(17) Å]. The 4bpy acts as a typical bridging ligand to form a 1D chain structure. All M-N and M-O bond distances as well as the bond angles around each MII center are in the expected ranges [12, 22]. It is worth noting that the dihedral angle between the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy plays an important role in the formation of these supramolecular frameworks. For 1, the 1D chains are assembled to form a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)⋅⋅⋅O(1B) separation is 3.308(3) Å and C(17)-H(17)⋅⋅⋅O(1B) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = -x+1, -y, -z+1] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S1). While for 2, the 1D chains are arranged into another 2D sheet by intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds [the C(17)⋅⋅⋅O(2A) separation is 3.330(4) Å and C(17)-H(17)⋅⋅⋅O(2A) angle is 131°, symmetry code A = x-1, y, z] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S2). However, there are no such weak interactions in complex 3.

elements.content: Although complex 4 also has a linear structure, it contains H2O ligands rather than EtOH (Fig. 1d). The asymmetric subunit in 4 is composed of half a CuII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and half an H2O ligand. As shown in Fig. 1a, each CuII is five-coordinated by carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and a single aqua ligand to complete a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment [Cu–O = 1.937(3) and 2.176(7); Cu–N = 2.077(4) Å] [25–27]. Cu(1) is connected to two adjacent CuII centers through the 4bpy bridges to result in a 1D chain.
elements.clean_text: Although complex 4 also has a linear structure, it contains H2O ligands rather than EtOH (Fig. 1d). The asymmetric subunit in 4 is composed of half a CuII center, one L ligand, half a 4bpy ligand, and half an H2O ligand. As shown in Fig. 1a, each CuII is five-coordinated by carboxylate O atoms from two monodentate L ligands, N atoms from two 4bpy ligands, and a single aqua ligand to complete a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment [Cu-O = 1.937(3) and 2.176(7); Cu-N = 2.077(4) Å] [25-27]. Cu(1) is connected to two adjacent CuII centers through the 4bpy bridges to result in a 1D chain.

elements.content: These 1D chains are assembled to form a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds [the O(1W)···O(1B) separation is 2.693(4) Å and O(1W)–H(1W)···O(1B) angle is 170.14(6)°, symmetry code A = x, y−1, z] [23, 24] (ESI-Fig. S3a). Meanwhile, in another crystallographic direction, the 1D chains are arranged into another supramolecular 2D sheet by intermolecular C−H···π supramolecular interaction by the edge-to-face orientation between the L and 4bpy rings [d = 3.753(2) Å; A = 150° in the C−H···π patterns] [13, 28, 29] (ESI-Fig. S3b). Finally, the 2D sheets are further linked into a 3D supramolecular network from the different crystallographic directions.

Meanwhile, in another crystallographic direction, the 1D chains are arranged into another supramolecular 2D sheet by intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interaction by the edge-to-face orientation between the L and 4bpy rings [d = 3.753(2) Å; A = 150° in the C-H⋅⋅⋅π patterns] [13, 28, 29] (ESI-Fig. S3b). Finally, the 2D sheets are further linked into a 3D supramolecular network from the different crystallographic directions.

elements.content: As typical aromatic carboxylate ligands, benzene-based carboxylic acids have been widely used to construct metal–organic coordination architectures [13–17]. The previously reported complexes [Zn3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(paH)(H2O)2.5, [Co3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(4-bpy)(H2O)3.5, and [Co(4bpy)(pa)2(H2O)2](paH)2 (paH = phenylacetic acid) [30], were constructed from paH and 4bpy (Chart 1), showing a 2D 44 framework, a 2D 44 framework, and a 1D chain, respectively. The four new complexes reported in this paper all show similar 1D fishbone-like chain structures. Although HL and paH are similar ligands (see Chart 1), their coordination chemistry is obviously different, presumably as a result of the different substituents. Thus, HL is more sterically hindered than paH, and hence, its complexes show simpler structures. In the supramolecular frameworks, the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy lie at different dihedral angles in complexes 1–4; there is not an obvious rule.
elements.clean_text: As typical aromatic carboxylate ligands, benzene-based carboxylic acids have been widely used to construct metal-organic coordination architectures [13-17]. The previously reported complexes [Zn3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(paH)(H2O)2.5, [Co3(4bpy)4(pa)4](NO3)2(4-bpy)(H2O)3.5, and [Co(4bpy)(pa)2(H2O)2](paH)2 (paH = phenylacetic acid) [30], were constructed from paH and 4bpy (Chart 1), showing a 2D 44 framework, a 2D 44 framework, and a 1D chain, respectively. The four new complexes reported in this paper all show similar 1D fishbone-like chain structures. Although HL and paH are similar ligands (see Chart 1), their coordination chemistry is obviously different, presumably as a result of the different substituents. Thus, HL is more sterically hindered than paH, and hence, its complexes show simpler structures. In the supramolecular frameworks, the aromatic rings in L and 4bpy lie at different dihedral angles in complexes 1-4; there is not an obvious rule.

elements.content: In general, the IR spectra of these complexes show features attributable to each component [31]. A broad band centered at ca. 3,642–3418 cm−1 is assigned to the O–H stretching of water or EtOH [12, 13, 15, 22]. The characteristic bands of carboxylate groups appeared in the usual regions at 1,640–1,568 cm−1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,456–1,402 cm−1 for the symmetric stretching vibrations [12, 13, 15, 22]. The Δν values [Δν = νas(COO−)−νs(COO−)] are 190 and 159 cm−1 for 1, 187 and 164 cm−1 for 2, 184 and 162 cm−1 for 3,202 and 154 cm−1 for 4, respectively, in good agreement with their s crystal structures [12, 13, 15, 22].
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic studies

In general, the IR spectra of these complexes show features attributable to each component [31]. A broad band centered at ca. 3,642-3418 cm-1 is assigned to the O-H stretching of water or EtOH [12, 13, 15, 22]. The characteristic bands of carboxylate groups appeared in the usual regions at 1,640-1,568 cm-1 for the antisymmetric stretching and 1,456-1,402 cm-1 for the symmetric stretching vibrations [12, 13, 15, 22]. The Δν values [Δν = νas(COO-)-νs(COO-)] are 190 and 159 cm-1 for 1, 187 and 164 cm-1 for 2, 184 and 162 cm-1 for 3,202 and 154 cm-1 for 4, respectively, in good agreement with their s crystal structures [12, 13, 15, 22].

elements.content: The solid-state luminescences of complexes 1–4 were investigated at room temperature (Fig. 2 and ESI-Figs. S4 and S5). We observed one emission peak at 338 nm for 1 (λex  = 303 nm), one emission peak at 382 nm for 2 (λex  =  279 nm), two emission peaks at 431 and 520 nm for 3 (λex = 380 nm), and two emission peaks at 431 and 520 nm for 4 (λex = 380 nm). Comparing with the emission peak of the free ligand HL at λmax = 383 nm upon excitation at λ = 279 nm, the emission peak of 2 can be tentatively assigned to intraligand charge transfer (LLCT) π*-π transitions, similar to the reported results on coordination polymers [11, 22]. For 1, a blueshift of 45 nm was observed compared with the emission of the free ligand. The emission of complex 1 might be assigned to a combination of CT and intraligand emission states, as reported for other complexes [11]. Complexes 3 and 4 show an obvious redshift relative to the free ligand, which may originate from the emission of 4bpy ligand [11, 22, 32].

elements.content: To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials used in the luminescence experiments on complexes 1–4, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments have been carried out. The experimental and computer-simulated XRPD patterns of the complexes are shown in ESI-Fig. S6. Although the experimental patterns have a few unindexed diffraction lines and some are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated from the single-crystal modes, it still can be considered that the bulk-synthesized materials and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD results

To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials used in the luminescence experiments on complexes 1-4, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) experiments have been carried out. The experimental and computer-simulated XRPD patterns of the complexes are shown in ESI-Fig. S6. Although the experimental patterns have a few unindexed diffraction lines and some are slightly broadened in comparison with those simulated from the single-crystal modes, it still can be considered that the bulk-synthesized materials and the as-grown crystals are homogeneous.

elements.content: In conclusion, we successfully obtained ZnII, CoII, NiII, and CuII complexes with 3,3-diphenylpropanoate ligands, together with 4,4′-bipyridine as auxiliary bridging ligands. The structural variations in the four complexes, compared with those of related ligands, can be attributed to the substituents of L. The intra- and/or intermolecular hydrogen bonds and C−H···π supramolecular interactions also play an important role in governing the formation of the crystal frameworks of 1–4. Complexes 1–4 emit strong fluorescence at room temperature, which may make them excellent candidates for purple or greenish purple fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we successfully obtained ZnII, CoII, NiII, and CuII complexes with 3,3-diphenylpropanoate ligands, together with 4,4'-bipyridine as auxiliary bridging ligands. The structural variations in the four complexes, compared with those of related ligands, can be attributed to the substituents of L. The intra- and/or intermolecular hydrogen bonds and C-H⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interactions also play an important role in governing the formation of the crystal frameworks of 1-4. Complexes 1-4 emit strong fluorescence at room temperature, which may make them excellent candidates for purple or greenish purple fluorescent materials.

A solution of HL (0.05 mmol) and 4bpy (0.05 mmol) in EtOH (10 mL) in the presence of excess 2,6-dimethylpyridine (ca. 0.05 mL for adjusting the pH to basic condition) was carefully layered on the top of an H2O solution (15 mL) of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.05 mmol) in a test tube.
